title: Defining the Genre
desc:
The start of the 20th century was defined by social unrest and global anxiety brought by the First World War and the Russian Revolution. There were widespread political tensions that caused the rise of totalitarian regimes and oligarchies that held control over the masses.

In this era, dystopian themes centered around politics ruled by the few and caste system where the lower class is subjected to oppressive actions by the upper class.

books.title: The Iron Heel
books.author: Jack London
books.desc: 'The Iron Heel' describes a world in which the division between the classes has deepened, creating a powerful Oligarchy that retains control through terror.

books.title: We
books.author: Yevgeny Zamyatin
books.desc: In a glass-enclosed city of absolute straight lines, ruled over by the all-powerful 'Benefactor', the citizens of the totalitarian society of OneState live out lives devoid of passion and creativity

title: Loss of Individuality and Rise of Facism
desc:
Political tensions and global anxieties worsened as the 1930s began. This period was defined by the rise of the Nazi Party headed by Adolf Hitler. Millions of Jews perished in the Holocaust and millions more were killed in the Second World War. Citizens under totalitarian regimes became subject of mass surveillance and censorhip. The Great Depression caused massive unemployment which led to widened gap between the rich and the poor.

Dystopian themes in this era focused on fear of state and loss of freedom caused by government propagandas and censorhip.
notable_event: Atomic Bombing in Nagasaki and Hiroshima

books.author: George Orwell
books.desc: People are subjected under the watchful eye of the state, where opinions are influenced by propaganda, and where the nation is in perpetual war against the enemies.

books.title: Brave New World
books.author: Aldous Huxley
books.desc: About a society where the truth is difficult to parse from within a vast sea of irrelevant information.

books.title: It Can't Happen Here
books.author: Sinclair Lewis
books.desc: a cautionary tale about the fragility of democracy, an alarming, eerily timeless look at how fascism could take hold in America.

title: Advancement of Technology
desc:
The arms race between the US and USSR paved way to the advancement of technology and eventually to the modernization of weapons of mass desctruction. Thanks to space travel (i.e. first Man on the Moon and first satellite Sputnik I) and the invention of personal computers, modern technologies defined this era.

Modern technologies and their potential negative effects on people became the central theme of this period.
notable_event: Creation of first Earth satellite, Sputnik I

books.title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
books.author: Philip K. Dick
books.desc: It was January 2021, and Rick Deckard had a license to kill. Somewhere among the hordes of humans out there, lurked several rogue androids. Deckard's assignment--find them and then..."retire" them. Trouble was, the androids all looked exactly like humans, and they didn't want to be found!

books.title: Stand on Zanzibar
books.author: John Brunner
books.desc: Stand on Zanzibar is a cross-section of a world overpopulated by the billions. Where society is squeezed into hive-living madness by god-like mega computers, mass-marketed psychedelic drugs, and mundane uses of genetic engineering.

books.title: A Clockwork Orange
books.author: Anthony Burgess
books.desc: In Anthony Burgess's influential nightmare vision of the future, criminals take over after dark. Teen gang leader Alex narrates in fantastically inventive slang that echoes the violent intensity of youth rebelling against society.

books.title: Make Room! Make Room!
books.author: Harry Harrison
books.desc: Society that is an overpopulated urban jungle, a divided class system—operating within an atmosphere of riots, food shortages, and senseless acts of violence.

books.title: Fahrenheit 451
books.author: Ray Bradbury
books.desc: Society where books are burned.

books.title: Harrison Bergeron
books.author: Kurt Vonnegut
books.desc: Every American is fully equal, meaning that no one is stupider, uglier, weaker, or slower than anyone else. The Handicapper General and a team of agents ensure that the laws of equality are enforced.

books.title: Player Piano
books.author: Kurt Vonnegut
books.desc: A chilling tale of engineer Paul Proteus, who must find a way to live in a world dominated by a supercomputer and run completely by machines.

title: Corporate Fascism and Body Anxieties
desc: More new dytopian themes emerged in this era. From political and social themes, dystopian fiction moved to new directions focusing on greedy corporations, commercialization of bodies, and biological issues concerning women. The threat of climate change also paved way to more ecological themes.
notable_event: First cloning of mammal, Dolly the Sheep

books.title: The Handmaid’s Tale
books.author: Margaret Atwood
books.desc: Set in a totalitarian theocracy where women have been reduced as baby makers in response to declining births. Women are not allowed to read.

books.title: The Children of Men
books.author: PD James
books.desc: About a world where the population has become infertile. Civilization is crumbling as suicide and despair become commonplace.

books.title: Neuromancer
books.author: William Gibson
books.desc: Awards, Neuromancer was the first fully-realized glimpse of humankind’s digital future—a shocking vision that has challenged our assumptions about our technology and ourselves, reinvented the way we speak and think, and forever altered the landscape of our imaginations.

books.title: Children of the Dust
books.author: Louise Lawrence
books.desc: After a nuclear war devastates the earth, a small band of people struggles for survival in a new world where children are born with strange mutations.

books.title: The Giver
books.author: Lois Lowry
books.desc: At the age of twelve, Jonas, a young boy from a seemingly utopian, futuristic world, is singled out to receive special training from The Giver, who alone holds the memories of the true joys and pain of life.

title: Self-discovery and Anti-conformism
desc: The dystopian fiction in this era is dominated by young adult narratives, focusing on the youth's self-discovery and their feeling of standing up against the authority or an established status quo. With the popularity of social media and the pressure to fit to society's standards, young adults are confronted with challenges that impact their identities.

books.title: The Hunger Games
books.author: Suzanne Collins
books.desc: In the ruins of a place once known as North America lies the nation of Panem, a shining Capitol surrounded by twelve outlying districts. The Capitol is harsh and cruel and keeps the districts in line by forcing them all to send one boy and one girl between the ages of twelve and eighteen to participate in the annual Hunger Games, a fight to the death on live TV.

books.title: Divergent
books.author: Veronica Roth
books.desc: A society is divided into five factions, each dedicated to the cultivation of a particular virtue—Candor (the honest), Abnegation (the selfless), Dauntless (the brave), Amity (the peaceful), and Erudite (the intelligent).

books.title: Maze Runner
books.author: James Dashner
books.desc: A group of young adults are trapped inside a maze. When they got out, they discovered that they were part of an experiment.

books.title: Uglies
books.author: Scott Westerfield
books.desc: Tally is about to turn sixteen, and she can't wait. In just a few weeks she'll have the operation that will turn her from a repellent ugly into a stunning pretty. And as a pretty, she'll be catapulted into a high-tech paradise where her only job is to have fun.

books.title: Ready Player One
books.author: Ernest Cline
books.desc: A society where the borderline between virtual reality and real world have become blurred

books.title: Feed
books.author: M.T. Anderson
books.desc: Identity crises, consumerism, and star-crossed teenage love in a futuristic society where people connect to the Internet via feeds implanted in their brains.
